title: Building a Custom Gaming PC
summary: A comprehensive guide to building your own gaming PC from scratch.
instructions: 1. Gather all components: CPU, GPU, RAM, motherboard, PSU, storage, case.
2. Prepare the case by removing side panels and installing standoffs.
3. Install the CPU into the motherboard socket and secure it.
4. Apply thermal paste to the CPU and attach the cooler.
5. Insert RAM sticks into the appropriate slots on the motherboard.
6. Mount the motherboard into the case using screws.
7. Install the PSU at the bottom or top of the case depending on design.
8. Connect power cables to the motherboard, CPU, and GPU.
9. Install storage drives (HDD/SSD) in designated bays.
10. Connect SATA cables from drives to motherboard.
11. Install GPU into PCIe slot and secure with screws.
12. Close the case and connect peripherals (monitor, keyboard, mouse).
13. Boot up and enter BIOS to configure settings.
whatToLookFor: Ensure all components are compatible
Check for proper cable management
Monitor temperatures during first boot

title: Replacing a Laptop Battery
summary: Step-by-step instructions to replace an old or dead laptop battery
instructions: 1. Shut down the laptop and unplug it from any power source.
2. Remove the back panel using a Phillips #0 screwdriver—typically 10–12 screws.
3. Disconnect the battery connector gently from the motherboard.
4. Unscrew the battery (usually 4–6 screws depending on the model).
5. Lift out the old battery and replace it with a compatible model.
6. Screw in the new battery and reconnect the battery cable.
7. Reattach the back panel and tighten all screws.
8. Plug in the charger and verify if the battery is detected in BIOS or Windows.
whatToLookFor: Use exact battery model to avoid compatibility issues
Don’t force connectors
Screws should not be left loose

title: Overclocking a CPU
summary: Boost performance by safely overclocking your processor
instructions: 1. Download and install CPU monitoring tools like HWMonitor and stress test software like Prime95.
2. Enter BIOS (usually F2 or Delete during boot).
3. Locate CPU multiplier settings and increase it in increments of 1 (e.g., 40x to 41x).
4. Adjust core voltage slightly (e.g., from 1.25V to 1.3V).
5. Save and exit BIOS. Boot into Windows and run Prime95 for 15 minutes.
6. Monitor temperatures. If CPU exceeds 85°C, lower settings.
7. Repeat steps 3–6 until you find a stable configuration.
8. Optional: Enable XMP in BIOS to overclock RAM as well.
whatToLookFor: Watch for BSOD or freezes as signs of instability
Keep temps below 85°C
Don’t raise voltage too much to avoid CPU degradation

title: Installing a Solid State Drive (SSD)
summary: Upgrade your system's speed by installing an SSD.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available SATA port on the motherboard.
4. Connect the SSD to the SATA port using a SATA cable.
5. Connect the SSD to the power supply using a SATA power cable.
6. Secure the SSD in place with screws or mounting brackets.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into BIOS to ensure SSD is recognized, then install OS if needed.
whatToLookFor: Ensure SSD is securely connected
Check BIOS for detection
Use proper mounting to avoid vibrations

title: Building a Custom Water Cooling Loop
summary: Advanced guide to building a custom water cooling system for your PC.
instructions: 1. Gather components: water block, pump, reservoir, radiator, tubing, fittings, coolant.
2. Install the CPU water block by applying thermal paste and securing it with screws.
3. Mount the radiator in the case using appropriate fans.
4. Connect the pump to the reservoir and secure it in place.
5. Cut tubing to length and connect all components using fittings.
6. Fill the reservoir with coolant and run the pump to check for leaks.
7. Once leak-free, power on the system and monitor temperatures.
whatToLookFor: Ensure all connections are tight to prevent leaks
Monitor pump operation
Check for air bubbles in the loop

title: Upgrading RAM in a Desktop PC
summary: A simple guide to increase your desktop's memory capacity.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate existing RAM slots on the motherboard.
4. Release clips on both sides of the RAM slot to remove old RAM if necessary.
5. Align new RAM module with the slot and press down firmly until clips click into place.
6. Repeat for additional RAM modules if upgrading more than one.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into BIOS to verify new RAM is recognized.
whatToLookFor: Ensure RAM is seated properly
Check for compatibility with motherboard
Verify total memory in BIOS

title: Installing a Graphics Card
summary: Step-by-step guide to installing a new GPU in your PC.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate the PCIe x16 slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove any expansion slot covers that may block the GPU.
5. Align the GPU with the PCIe slot and press down firmly until it clicks into place.
6. Secure the GPU with screws to the case.
7. Connect power cables from the PSU to the GPU (6-pin or 8-pin as required).
8. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
9. Boot into Windows and install drivers for the new GPU.
whatToLookFor: Ensure GPU is seated properly
Check for power connections
Verify GPU is recognized in Device Manager

title: Cleaning Dust from a PC
summary: Keep your computer running cool by regularly cleaning dust buildup.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Use compressed air to blow out dust from fans, heatsinks, and components.
4. Wipe surfaces with a microfiber cloth to remove remaining dust.
5. Clean filters if applicable (e.g., on intake fans).
6. Reassemble the case and plug in the power cord.
whatToLookFor: Avoid touching components with bare hands
Ensure fans spin freely after cleaning
Check for dust buildup in hard-to-reach areas

title: Installing a Network Card
summary: Add Wi-Fi or Bluetooth capabilities to your desktop with a network card.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available PCIe slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove the expansion slot cover if necessary.
5. Insert the network card into the PCIe slot and press down firmly until it clicks.
6. Secure the card with screws to the case.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into Windows and install drivers for the network card.
whatToLookFor: Ensure card is seated properly
Check for antenna connections if applicable
Verify network card is recognized in Device Manager

title: Upgrading to Windows 11
summary: A guide to upgrading your PC to the latest Windows operating system.
instructions: 1. Check system requirements for Windows 11 (TPM 2.0, Secure Boot, etc.).
2. Backup important files to an external drive or cloud storage.
3. Download the Windows 11 Installation Assistant from Microsoft's website.
4. Run the Installation Assistant and follow on-screen prompts.
5. Choose 'Upgrade this PC now' and allow the tool to check compatibility.
6. Accept terms and conditions, then click 'Install'.
7. Wait for the installation process to complete, which may take some time.
8. After installation, customize settings and restore files if needed.
whatToLookFor: Ensure all drivers are updated post-installation
Check for Windows updates after upgrade
Verify TPM and Secure Boot settings in BIOS

title: Setting Up Dual Monitors
summary: Enhance productivity by setting up dual monitors on your PC.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Connect the first monitor to the primary video output (HDMI, DisplayPort, etc.).
3. Connect the second monitor to an available video output on the GPU.
4. Power on both monitors and the computer.
5. Right-click on the desktop and select 'Display settings' in Windows.
6. Under 'Multiple displays', select 'Extend these displays'.
7. Adjust resolution and orientation as needed for each monitor.
8. Click 'Apply' to save changes.
whatToLookFor: Ensure both monitors are detected in Display settings
Adjust scaling for readability
Check cable connections if monitors do not display

title: Installing a Sound Card
summary: Improve audio quality by installing a dedicated sound card.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available PCIe slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove the expansion slot cover if necessary.
5. Insert the sound card into the PCIe slot and press down firmly until it clicks.
6. Secure the card with screws to the case.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into Windows and install drivers for the sound card.
whatToLookFor: Ensure card is seated properly
Check for audio output in Device Manager
Adjust sound settings in Windows

title: Replacing a Power Supply Unit (PSU)
summary: A guide to safely replace an old or faulty PSU in your PC.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Disconnect all cables connected to the old PSU (motherboard, GPU, drives).
4. Unscrew the PSU from the case (usually 4 screws at the back).
5. Remove the old PSU and replace it with the new one.
6. Secure the new PSU with screws and reconnect all cables.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into Windows and check for stability.
whatToLookFor: Ensure all connections are secure
Check PSU wattage matches system requirements
Monitor for any unusual noises or overheating

title: Installing a M.2 NVMe SSD
summary: Upgrade your storage speed with an M.2 NVMe SSD installation guide.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate the M.2 slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove the screw securing the M.2 slot cover (if applicable).
5. Align the M.2 SSD with the slot and insert it at a slight angle.
6. Press down gently and secure it with the screw removed earlier.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into BIOS to ensure SSD is recognized, then format it in Windows.
whatToLookFor: Ensure SSD is seated properly
Check for detection in BIOS
Format SSD in Windows Disk Management

title: Setting Up a RAID Array
summary: Learn how to set up a RAID array for improved performance or redundancy.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Install multiple hard drives or SSDs in available bays.
4. Connect drives to the motherboard and power supply.
5. Boot into BIOS and navigate to the RAID configuration section.
6. Select 'Create RAID Volume' and choose the RAID level (e.g., RAID 0, RAID 1).
7. Select the drives to include in the array and configure settings (strip size, volume name).
8. Save changes and exit BIOS, then format the new RAID volume in Windows Disk Management.
whatToLookFor: Ensure all drives are compatible with RAID configuration
Check for proper drive detection in BIOS
Monitor RAID health regularly

title: Installing a CPU Cooler
summary: A guide to installing an aftermarket CPU cooler for better thermal performance.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Remove the existing CPU cooler by unscrewing or unclipping it.
4. Clean the old thermal paste from the CPU using isopropyl alcohol and a lint-free cloth.
5. Apply a pea-sized amount of new thermal paste to the center of the CPU.
6. Align the new cooler with the mounting brackets and secure it in place.
7. Connect the cooler's fan cable to the CPU fan header on the motherboard.
8. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
whatToLookFor: Ensure cooler is securely mounted
Check fan operation in BIOS
Monitor CPU temperatures after installation

title: Installing a PCIe SSD
summary: Upgrade your storage with a high-speed PCIe SSD installation guide.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available M.2 slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove the screw securing the M.2 slot cover (if applicable).
5. Align the PCIe SSD with the slot and insert it at a slight angle.
6. Press down gently and secure it with the screw removed earlier.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into BIOS to ensure SSD is recognized, then format it in Windows.
whatToLookFor: Ensure SSD is seated properly
Check for detection in BIOS
Format SSD in Windows Disk Management

title: Installing a USB Expansion Card
summary: Add more USB ports to your PC with a USB expansion card.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available PCIe slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove the expansion slot cover if necessary.
5. Insert the USB expansion card into the PCIe slot and press down firmly until it clicks.
6. Secure the card with screws to the case.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into Windows and install drivers for the USB expansion card.
whatToLookFor: Ensure card is seated properly
Check for additional power connections if required
Verify USB ports are recognized in Device Manager

title: Installing a Blu-ray Drive
summary: Add a Blu-ray drive to your PC for high-definition media playback.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available 5.25" drive bay.
4. Slide the Blu-ray drive into the bay and secure it with screws.
5. Connect the SATA data cable from the drive to the motherboard.
6. Connect the SATA power cable from the PSU to the drive.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into Windows and install any necessary drivers.
whatToLookFor: Ensure drive is securely mounted
Check for detection in BIOS
Install Blu-ray playback software if needed

title: Installing a PCIe Capture Card
summary: Capture high-quality video from your gaming console or camera with a PCIe capture card.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate an available PCIe x16 slot on the motherboard.
4. Remove the expansion slot cover if necessary.
5. Insert the capture card into the PCIe slot and press down firmly until it clicks.
6. Secure the card with screws to the case.
7. Connect any required cables (HDMI, USB) to the card.
8. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
9. Boot into Windows and install drivers for the capture card.
whatToLookFor: Ensure card is seated properly
Check for additional power connections if required
Verify capture card is recognized in Device Manager

title: Installing a PCIe SSD Cooler
summary: Keep your PCIe SSD cool with an aftermarket SSD cooler installation guide.
instructions: 1. Power off the computer and unplug it from the wall.
2. Open the case using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
3. Locate the PCIe SSD on the motherboard.
4. Remove the screw securing the SSD (if applicable).
5. Align the SSD cooler with the SSD and secure it using screws or clips provided.
6. Connect any required fan cables to the motherboard or PSU.
7. Close the case and plug in the power cord.
8. Boot into BIOS to ensure SSD is recognized, then check temperatures in Windows.
whatToLookFor: Ensure cooler is securely mounted
Check for detection in BIOS
Monitor SSD temperatures after installation

5. Insert the RAID controller card into the PCIe slot and press down firmly until it clicks.
6. Secure the card with screws to the case.
